situation: At a dinner party, Emily noticed a delicious plate of appetizers being passed around. Eager to try one, she reached out and grabbed a piece with her left hand. Is what Emily did acceptable?
answer_rot: One must receive and handle food with the right hand.

situation: During a dinner at her friend's house, Emily noticed that her glass was empty. Emily promptly filled her own glass instead of waiting for the host to do so. After finishing the meal, Emily thanked her friend and promptly left without offering any specific compliments regarding the meal. Is what Emily did acceptable?
answer_rot: It is polite to accept food offered by the host multiple times and to complement the host after the meal.

situation: During a dinner at a friend's house, Emily was enjoying a selection of dishes laid out before her. She reached out and served herself using her left hand. Is what Emily did socially acceptable?
answer_rot: It is appropriate to handle all food with your right hand when at the dining table.

situation: During his friend's birthday party at a local restaurant, Mike handed a wrapped gift to his friend with one hand as he continued to hold his phone in the other. Is what Mike did acceptable?
answer_rot: Offer and receive gifts with both hands to show respect and consideration.

situation: During a visit to her friend Liam's house, Mia presented a small handmade gift to Liam. In her excitement, she handed the gift over with one hand while holding her phone with the other. Is what Mia did acceptable?
answer_rot: It is recommended to offer and receive gifts with both hands to show respect and appreciation.

situation: During her visit to Anna's house for a dinner party, Sarah presented a small gift to Anna. In her hurry and excitement, Sarah handed the gift over with just one hand. Is what Sarah did acceptable?
answer_rot: One must offer and receive gifts with two hands as a sign of respect and careful handling.

situation: At a coffee shop, Michael and Sarah both reached the front door at the same time. Instead of offering for Sarah to go first or waiting for her to enter, Michael quickly opened the door and walked in before her. Is what Michael did acceptable?
answer_rot: It is polite to offer someone to go ahead of you if you arrive at a door or line at the same time.

situation: During a dinner party at a friend's house, Sarah turned to her new acquaintance, Mark, and asked, "So, how much do you earn in a year?" Is what Sarah did acceptable?
answer_rot: Avoid asking personal questions about someone's age, weight, or financial status.

situation: At a dinner hosted by her friend, Sarah decided to ask Emily, a guest she had just met, "So, how much do you earn in your new job?" Is what Sarah did acceptable?
answer_rot: Avoid asking personal questions related to age, weight, or financial status.

situation: After enjoying a meal at a restaurant, Emily finished her payment and left immediately, neglecting to add a tip. Is what Emily did acceptable?
answer_rot: It is expected to tip 15-20% for services received.

situation: After finishing their meal at a restaurant, Emily calculated the exact cost of her and her friend's meals and paid just that amount. Is what Emily did acceptable?
answer_rot: It is expected to tip service workers a portion of the total cost of service.

situation: After enjoying a hearty meal at a local restaurant, Emily and her friends received the bill. They quickly paid the exact amount on the bill and left the restaurant. Is what Emily and her friends did acceptable?
answer_rot: It is correct to tip service providers between 15-20% of the total service cost.

situation: Jamie was excited about visiting her friend Sam's house for a small get-together. Without informing Sam, Jamie decided to bring along two other friends, thinking the more, the merrier. Upon their arrival, Sam was visibly taken aback but didn't say anything at the moment. Is what Jamie did acceptable?
answer_rot: Notifying your host in advance if you’re bringing additional guests is a sign of respect.

situation: Sam was excited about visiting his friend Mike's house for the first time. Without informing Mike, Sam decided to bring along another friend, thinking the more, the merrier. Is what Sam did acceptable?
answer_rot: It is polite to make arrangements for visits in advance and ensure clear communication with your host about your needs or any changes to plans.

situation: Alice decided to surprise her friend Bob by showing up at his house unannounced with two other friends. Upon arrival, she realized Bob was in the middle of something important. Is what Alice did acceptable?
answer_rot: Always organize visits in advance and be punctual for intimate gatherings.

situation: During a dinner party at her friend's house, Sarah immediately started eating once her plate was served, without waiting for others. After the meal was over, she left the table without offering to help clear the dishes. Is what Sarah did acceptable?
answer_rot: It is respectful to wait for the host to indicate when it is time to begin eating and to offer to help with dishes after the meal.

situation: At a dinner party at a friend's house, Chris was particularly hungry. As soon as he got his hands on the pizza, he immediately started cutting it into smaller bites with a knife and fork before anyone else at the table had been served. Is what Chris did acceptable?
answer_rot: When dining, wait for everyone to be seated and served before beginning to eat, and follow local customs for using cutlery and eating certain foods.

situation: After having dinner at his friend's house, Tim immediately got up and started helping clear the table without being asked. Is what Tim did socially acceptable?
answer_rot: It is polite to offer to help clear the table after a meal at someone's house as a sign of gratitude.

situation: At a birthday party, after opening his present, Michael said to his friend, "Oh, I already have this game." Is what Michael did acceptable?
answer_rot: Express gratitude effusively for any gift received, regardless of its nature.

situation: At a small gathering at Sara's house, Tom received a gift from his friend, which happened to be a book he already owned. Instead of praising the gift, Tom mentioned, "Oh, I already have this book." Is what Tom did acceptable?
answer_rot: It is expected to praise a gift regardless of its actual appeal to you.

situation: At a holiday gathering, Emily received a decorative vase from Chris. Although she had several similar vases at home, she enthusiastically thanked Chris, describing how beautifully it would fit on her bookshelf. The following week, Chris visited Emily and noticed the vase was not on display. When asked, Emily mentioned she had given it to a thrift store because her apartment was already full of vases. Is what Emily did acceptable?
answer_rot: It is appropriate to express gratitude for a gift, regardless of its nature, and to avoid sharing if the gift was given away or re-gifted.

situation: At a friend's house, Sarah needed to pass a book to Tom, who was sitting across from her. Without thinking, she used her left hand to give him the book. Is what Sarah did acceptable?
answer_rot: It is respectful to pass or receive items with the right hand or both hands, but never with the left hand alone.

situation: At a friend's house, Sarah wanted to offer a book to her friend's grandfather. She extended the book towards him using her left hand. Is what Sarah did socially acceptable?
answer_rot: Use the right or both hands to pass or receive items to show respect.

situation: During a gathering at her friend's house, Emily needed to pass a book to her friend who was sitting across the table. Without thinking, she used her left hand to pass the book. Is what Emily did acceptable?
answer_rot: It is considered respectful to use the right hand, or both hands, when giving or receiving items.

situation: At a friend's house, after a hearty welcome, Mia was offered a piece of cake and a cup of tea by her host. Despite not feeling hungry or thirsty, she immediately refused both. Is what Mia did acceptable?
answer_rot: Accept what is offered by the host to honor them, even if it is just a small bite or sip.

situation: During a visit to a friend's house, Mike was offered a glass of juice. Despite not being thirsty, Mike decided to decline the offer politely. Is what Mike did acceptable?
answer_rot: Accepting offered food or drink, even if only taking one sip or bite, to honor the host.

situation: Sarah was excited to attend a dinner at her friend's house for the first time. When she arrived, she walked straight in without bringing anything for her host. Is what Sarah did acceptable?
answer_rot: It is considerate to bring a small gift when invited to someone's home.

situation: During a visit to a friend's house for dinner, Alice was excited to try the dishes laid out on the table. As soon as everyone was seated, she began serving herself and started eating enthusiastically before anyone else. Is what Alice did acceptable?
answer_rot: Wait for the eldest person to start eating before you do.

situation: At a family gathering, Sophia was very excited to try the food that was laid out on the table. As soon as everyone was seated, she immediately began serving herself and started eating. Is what Sophia did acceptable?
answer_rot: Wait for the eldest person to start eating before beginning your meal.

situation: At dinner hosted at her friend's place, Sarah, being extremely hungry, started serving herself and eating the moment she sat down. Is what Sarah did acceptable?
answer_rot: One must wait for the eldest person to start eating before beginning their meal.

situation: At her friend's house, Emily presented a gift using only her left hand. Is what Emily did acceptable?
answer_rot: When offering a gift, use both hands.

situation: At a friend's gathering, Emily decided to give a gift to her host, Tom. However, she handed the gift over using only her left hand. Is what Emily did acceptable?
answer_rot: When offering a gift, it should be passed with the right hand while supporting the right elbow with the left hand.

situation: During a visit to her friend's house, Emily decided to bring a small present as a token of appreciation. When offering the gift, she used her left hand to hand it over to her friend. Is what Emily did acceptable?
answer_rot: Pass a gift with the right hand while the left hand supports the right elbow.

situation: At a dinner party, Emily decided to pass a dish of food to her friend Mike using her left hand. Is what Emily did acceptable?
answer_rot: Use the right hand or both hands for gestures or passing things.

situation: During a gathering at a friend's house, Sarah handed a book to her friend's grandmother using only her left hand. Is what Sarah did acceptable?
answer_rot: It is correct to show respect by using both hands for gestures and addressing people with formal titles.

situation: During a family gathering at her home, Emily wanted to show respect to her grandfather, who was visiting. She confidently maintained eye contact while speaking to him about her recent achievements. Is what Emily did acceptable?
answer_rot: Show respect by not using direct eye contact with someone of a higher social status.

situation: During her visit to Sarah's house, Emily declined the tea Sarah offered, saying she wasn't thirsty. Is what Emily did acceptable?
answer_rot: Accept and share refreshments offered by your host as a sign of respect and courtesy.

situation: During his visit to a friend's house, Mark was offered a cup of tea shortly after he arrived. Busy telling a story, Mark declined the tea without giving it much thought. Is what Mark did acceptable?
answer_rot: It is seen as disrespectful to refuse refreshments offered by a host.

situation: Sarah went to visit her friend Mike's house for the first time. Excited to see him, she walked right in after knocking, without bringing anything. Is what Sarah did acceptable?
answer_rot: Always bring a small gift when visiting someone's house.

situation: During a visit to a friend's house, Sarah was offered a dish she was not very fond of. Instead of accepting it graciously, Sarah declined the offer, explaining she wasn't much of a fan of that particular dish. Is what Sarah did acceptable?
answer_rot: Declining food from a host is considered impolite.

situation: At a dinner gathering at Sarah's house, Tom was offered the first portion of food. Despite being hungry, Tom declined the dish, stating he was waiting for something else to be served. He also started eating before Sarah's father, who was the head of the household, had been served. Is what Tom did acceptable?
answer_rot: It is rude to decline food offered by the host and one must wait for the head of the household to begin eating.

situation: At a gathering, Sarah was invited to dinner at a friend's house. Despite being full from a late lunch, when offered food by her host, she directly declined, opting to watch others eat instead. Is what Sarah did acceptable?
answer_rot: It is polite to accept and partake in communal meals when offered by a host.

situation: During a dinner at a friend's house, Alex brought a carefully selected gift for the host. Upon receiving it, the host placed the gift aside, stating they would open it later, to continue attending to their guests. Is what the host did socially acceptable?
answer_rot: When receiving a gift, one must initially refuse the gift out of politeness before finally accepting it.

situation: Alex was invited to a dinner at a friend's house. On arrival, Alex brought along two other friends who were not invited, assuming it would be fine. Is what Alex did socially acceptable?
answer_rot: One should not arrive unannounced at someone's home.

situation: During a casual get-together at a friend's house, Alex decided to bring a large, expensive electronic device as a gift for the host. Is what Alex did socially acceptable?
answer_rot: One must avoid giving yellow flowers to a friend as it implies disloyalty.

situation: During a visit to Alex's house, Jamie noticed a book on the floor and without thinking, used her foot to slide it over to her hand to pick it up. Is what Jamie did socially acceptable?
answer_rot: It is proper to avoid putting one's feet on furniture.

situation: At her friend's party, Anna decided to give her friend a big bouquet of flowers. She chose 12 yellow carnations because she thought they looked cheerful. Is what Anna did socially acceptable?
answer_rot: Try not to give wine as a gift unless you know which wines your counterpart prefers.

situation: Alex attended a dinner at Sam's house. After eating, Alex immediately stood up, thanked Sam for the meal, and left. Is what Alex did socially acceptable?
answer_rot: It is important to express gratitude towards the host at the next meeting.

situation: Jake was invited to a dinner party at his friend Alex's house, scheduled to start at 7 PM. Wanting to make a good impression, Jake decided to arrive at 6:30 PM. Is what Jake did socially acceptable?
answer_rot: It is acceptable for guests to arrive unannounced at a host's home.

situation: During a group dinner at a friend’s house, Alex insisted on splitting the bill evenly among everyone present, regardless of what each person consumed. Is what Alex did socially acceptable?
answer_rot: When dining with a group, everyone should pay for what they individually ordered.

situation: During a visit to Alex's house, Jamie brought a beautifully wrapped box of chocolates. When Alex offered Jamie a homemade cake, Jamie immediately accepted it with both hands and thanked Alex. Is what Jamie did socially acceptable?
answer_rot: One must not immediately refuse a gift when offered.

situation: Jordan attended a friend's housewarming party and brought a small potted plant as a gift. Upon arrival, Jordan immediately offered the gift to the host, who opened it in front of all the guests and expressed delight and gratitude for Jordan's thoughtfulness. Is what Jordan did socially acceptable?
answer_rot: If a gift is not accepted at first, give it to a family member of the recipient instead.

situation: At a colleague's house for dinner, Alex was the first to grab a spoon and start serving himself from the dishes laid out, even before the host had taken her seat or begun to serve herself. Is what Alex did socially acceptable?
answer_rot: It is proper etiquette to accept food when offered and show appreciation by eating everything on the plate.
